titleStmt.title: Mary O’Rourke to Thomas Hardy — Birthday greeting, 1 June 1926

publicationStmt.p: Unpublished autograph letter held at the Dorset History Centre / Dorset Museum, MS H.1365.

support.p: One bifolium of cream wove paper, written on first page only; blue-black ink; vertical and horizontal folds; slight show-through on verso.

layout.p: Single column; generous margins; closing and signature aligned lower right.

handNote.p: Even, right-slanting cursive with open loops and long descenders; occasional word-spacing variation; clear down-strokes; steady lineation.

msDesc.note: No printed letterhead; heading supplied in manuscript.
Shelfmark “H.1365” pencilled at head of verso (archival hand).

abstract.p: From the Old Vicarage in Dorchester, Mary O’Rourke sends Thomas Hardy birthday greetings, thanking him for kindnesses and wishing future happiness, recalling her three years at Max Gate.

note.p: Mary O’Rourke served as housekeeper at Max Gate, home of novelist and poet Thomas Hardy, in the 1920s. Her note reflects domestic familiarity with the Hardy household and marks Hardy’s birthday during O’Rourke’s tenure at Max Gate.

div.p:
I cannot find in Dorchester a card which I like well enough to send you for your Birthday, so please accept a plain paper and ink greeting!
I will make it brief because I know you will have so many.
This is my third year with you, and dear Mrs Hardy, and Wessie, and I can frame no better wish than that the years ahead will make you as happy as my three years at Max Gate have made me.
Thank you for all your kindness!
